The continuous flow selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol to 2-butene-1,4-diol places high demands on the activity and stability of the catalyst. Herein, an intermetallic PtZn/ZnO catalyst is designed by using the coupling strategy of strong electrostatic adsorption and subsequent reactive metal-support interaction. The TOF value of the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst, including PtZn intermetallic compound with electron-rich Ptδ- active sites, reaches 1421.6 h−1, which is almost 8 times higher than that of Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst with monometallic Pt as active sites. The activation energy of Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst (35.5 kJ mol−1) is significantly lower than that of Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst with 49.9 kJ mol−1. In addition, the Pt/ZnO-H500 presents high stability in the continuous flow selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol to 2-butene-1,4-diol for 75 h. These results suggest the intermetallic PtZn/ZnO presents as an alternative Pt-based catalyst without modification by toxic metals or organic matter and is a promising catalyst for directional hydrogenation in fine chemical synthesis. Graphical Abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation 1, 4-Butynediol Intermetallic PtZn Electronic effect Reactive metal-support interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Enols as high-value industrial raw materials are widely used in nutritional products, flavors and fragrances, new materials, pharmaceuticals, and pesticides [1–3]. The preparation of the corresponding enol from selective catalytic hydrogenation of alkynol is one of the important processes. The commercial catalytic material for selective hydrogenation of alkynol is the Lindlar catalyst [4]. However, the addition of toxic substances such as lead acetate and pyridine is necessary to obtain high enol selectivity, which does not meet the development requirements of green chemistry. Therefore, the development of a new generation of efficient and environmentally friendly catalytic materials has important economic value and application prospects. In recent years, the selective hydrogenation of alkynols, especially 1,4-butynediol (BYD), have achieved some outstanding and interesting results on Pt-based noble metal catalysts [5–10]. Rode et al. fund that the presence of ammonia or the alkali metal doping on the monometallic Pt nanoparticles catalysts had greatly tune the adsorption of carbine type intermediates, boosting the selectivity to 1,4-butenediol (BED) in the hydrogenation of BYD [5,6]. In our previous research, it was found that the Pt@ZIF-8 catalyst presented good catalytic performance and excellent selectivity for the hydrogenation of BYD without the addition of other active agent and stabilizers, because that the active Pt NPs were modified due to the presence of Zn2+ and N-containing organic ligands in ZIF-8 [7]. Recently, the effects of Zn content on the physicochemical properties and catalytic performances of bimetallic PtZnx/CeO2 catalysts were studied in the selective hydrogenation of BYD [10]. Both the Ptδ−-Znδ+ structure formed by electron transfer from Zn to Pt and decreased Pt surface density caused by Zn were found to profoundly affect the adsorption structures and bonding strength of the reactant, intermediates, and hydrogen, thus leading to more favorable reaction energetics. In a word, the geometric and electronic structure, chemical state, and morphology of Pt nanoparticles and support have been tuned generally for enhancing the selectivity to BED, which will govern the adsorption, activation, and desorption behavior of reactants and intermediates, promoting the selective hydrogenation of CC bonds to CC bonds as well as inhibiting the cleavage of C-OH bonds in BYD. Generally, the noble metal Pt has the capacity to generate intermetallic compounds when combined with secondary metals such as Sn, In, Ga, Si, or Zn. The presence of these secondary metals serves to modulate the d-band electronic structure of Pt, effectively segregating its active sites and consequently exerting precise control over its selective hydrogenation capabilities [10–13]. The key to success for selective hydrogenation of alkynols is reasonably designing of Pt-based intermetallic compounds catalysts to optimize the ratio of surface to volume for catalytic sites, enhance reactivity to its utmost potential, and ensure stability. For heterogenous catalysts synthesized with readily reducible metal oxides such as ZnO as the support, the reactive interactions between the metal and the support play a pivotal role in determining the catalytic performances [14,15]. The application of heat treatment plays a crucial role in inducing phase transitions within the metallic system. The temperature at which reduction occurs directly impacts the quantity of Zn atoms within the metal, as well as their kinetic energy. Consequently, these factors influence the phase composition and nanoparticle size of the PtZn intermetallic compound, thereby exerting varied degrees of modulation on the geometry and electron density of the catalytically active metallic Pt. The increase in reduction temperature facilitates superior thermal oscillation of the reduced Zn atoms, thereby promoting the diffusion of the metallic Zn and facilitating the formation of well-ordered intermetallic compounds. However, the elevated temperature also leads to a decrease in the specific surface area of the substrate, which adversely affects the catalytic activity of the reaction. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate the optimal reduction temperature to minimize the agglomeration of nanoparticles during the synthesis of PtZn intermetallic compound. In addition, the loading technique employed for Pt nanoparticles plays a pivotal role in the performance of catalyst, as a highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles configuration fosters the formation of intermetallic compound phases. The strong electrostatic adsorption method allows the charged active metal precursors to be firmly adsorbed on the surface of the carrier by adjusting the pH of the carrier suspension [16]. Notably, this approach proves suitable for a wide range of supports other than molecular sieves, and the catalysts synthesized by this method exhibit a stronger metal-support interaction due to the robust binding of opposite charges, allowing the active metal to be uniformly dispersed on the surface of the support. The catalysts prepared by this method possess the advantages of diminutive metal nanoparticles, uniform dispersion, and pronounced bimetallic alloying, rendering it an exceptional method for fabricating loaded intermetallic catalysts. In this work, Pt/ZnO catalysts are fabricated by the reactive metal-support interaction strategy and investigated in the continuous-flow selective hydrogenation of BYD. The influence of different reduction temperatures on the structure and performance of Pt/ZnO catalysts is investigated with emphasis on the conformational relationship analysis to illustrate the origin of the excellent BYD selective hydrogenation performance of PtZn intermetallic compound. Among the catalysts studied, the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst stands out for its exceptional selectivity to BED and higher turnover frequency (TOF). Combined reaction kinetic experiments and in-situ infrared characterizations unveil that the local electron-abundant Pt enveloped by Zn atoms exhibits the potential to facilitate the BYD semi-hydrogenation route by mitigating the activation energy, as well as suppress the over-hydrogenation route by modulating the adsorption affinity and configuration of BED. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The information of raw materials involved in this work was listed in Supplementary Material. The catalyst was prepared by strong electrostatic adsorption with controlling the theoretical loadings of Pt at 1%. The measurement of the point of zero charge (PZC) of ZnO and chloroplatinate anion adsorption curves are shown in Figure S1 in Supplementary Material. The H2PtCl6 solution was diluted to 68 mL with deionized water and the pH was adjusted to an optimum adsorption pH of 2.6. 2.0 g of ZnO support (controlled surface loading of 1000 m2 L−1) was then added to the solution and the liquid was removed by filtration after stirring with 12 h. The precipitate was dried overnight at 110 °C and subsequently roasted within a tube furnace at 400 °C for 2 h under an atmosphere of 20 mL min−1 O2 and 40 mL min−1 Ar. Finally, the sample was reduced in H2 atmosphere at a certain temperature (200 °C, 400 °C, 500 °C and 600 °C) for catalytic evaluation and characterization, which is marked as Pt/ZnO-H200, Pt/ZnO-H400, Pt/ZnO-H500, and Pt/ZnO-H600, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The structure and composition of samples were investigated with inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The detail information was presented in Supplementary Material. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO chemisorption (CO-Chem) analyses were conducted on the AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. In order to estimate the number of active meter sites of the catalyst and determine the TOF value, a CO: Pt stoichiometry ratio of 1:1 was assumed. The CO chemsorption-diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (CO-DRIFTS) measurements on the Pt/ZnO sample were conducted using a Thermo Nicolet i50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a Praying Mantis DRIFTS reactor from Harrick Scientific. The experimental process referred to our previous report [10]. 2.3 Selective hydrogenation of BYD in continuous-flow reactor The selective hydrogenation of BYD over as-prepared Pt/ZnO catalysts was carried out within a continuous-flow fixed bed reactor, as illustrated in Figure S2. The reaction conditions were listed in the Table S1. Before conducting the experiment, the assessment of mass transfer limitation over the Pt/ZnO catalysts was calculated, as depicted in the Supplementary Material. The specific testing process can refer to the previous report [10]. The contact time, conversion (X) of BYD, selectivity (Si) of products, and the TOF were defined as follows: (1) Contact time (gcat h mol−1) = mcat/(F×60) (2) X = (n0 – nt)/n0 × 100% (3) Si = ni/Σni × 100% (4) TOF (h−1) = (F × 60 × X)/(ntotal × DPt) where mcat (g) denoted the catalyst mass, F (mol min−1) represented the molar flow rate of reactant, n0 and nt referred to the moles of reactant in the feed and product, respectively, ni was the mole of product i and Σni assigned the total moles of products. Additionally, ntotal was the mole of Pt in the catalyst, while DPt was the dispersion of Pt metal, quantified through the measurement of CO-Chem. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties To achieve optimal dispersion of metallic active sites on metal oxides support and strengthen the anchoring of metal nanoparticles on the surface of support, the strong electrostatic adsorption and reactive metal-support interaction coupling strategy has been applied in the synthesis process of Pt/ZnO catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1a. Initially, the PZC of the ZnO support is determined to be 7.3, as shown in Figure S1a, signifying that the metallic anion (PtCl6)2- exhibits a preference for adsorption onto the ZnO support when the pH of solution (under acidic conditions) approaches to the PZC value. As shown in Figure S1b, the metal uptake of SEA reaches its peak at the initial pH of 2.6, with a value of 1.5 μmol m−2. Through controlling the pH of solution, the Pt with 1% loadings has been impregnated on the ZnO support, which has been monitored by ICP-OES. For metallic oxide supported Pt-based catalysts, the interaction between Pt and the oxide is heavily affected by the calcination temperature in air or oxygen atmosphere. This, in turn, results in an electron-deficient state of the Pt atoms, which hampers the achievement of highly efficient in selectivity hydrogenation reactions. As depicted in Fig. 1b, the calcination process for the Pt/ZnO precursor is determined by TG-DTA analysis. Clearly, the initial weight loss is attributed to the desorption of gas and water molecules. The most substantial weight loss peak is observed at 250 °C, which is attributed to the pyrolysis of the catalyst precursor. In addition, the weight loss at around 750 °C is ascribed to the sublimation of ZnO. The roasting temperature is therefore set at 400 °C to ensure the thermal stability of the catalyst. H2-TPR experiment is conducted on the calcined Pt/ZnO sample, revealing a reduction curve illustrated in Fig. 1c. This curve exhibits three distinct reduction peaks. Notably, the most prominent reduction peak, occurring at 132 °C, corresponds to the reduction of Pt2+ species. This can be attributed to the high dispersion of Pt sites in the catalyst prepared by the strong electrostatic adsorption method, resulting in a convergence of the chemical state of the Pt species in the sample. A smaller peak at 363 °C can be ascribed to the Pt4+ species, which arises from the strong interaction between Pt species and the ZnO support. Furthermore, the peak observed at a higher temperature (494 °C) may be assigned to the reduction of ZnO in contact with Pt nanoparticles. The Pt species act as catalysts, facilitating the reduction process [17]. Remarkably, by subjecting the Pt/ZnO sample to different reduction temperatures, the interaction between Pt and ZnO can be significantly modified, resulting in the formation of intermetallic PtZn on the ZnO support. This alteration effectively modulates the electronic and geometrical state of the Pt metal, thereby exerting diverse effects on the selective hydrogenation of BYD. The Pt/ZnO samples reduced at different temperatures are characterized by XRD, and the results are shown in Fig. 2. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the ZnO with the Wurtzite phase (ICDD No. 36–1451) are well detected irrespective of the processing conditions [18,19]. No diffraction peaks corresponding to Pt are detected in any of the samples, which may be attributed to the uniformly distributed Pt nanoparticles on the ZnO support due to the strong electrostatic adsorption effect. However, in the case of the Pt/ZnO-H500 sample, a characteristic peak at 40.8° is observed, which is attributed to the (111) face of PtZn intermetallic compound (ICDD No. 06–0604), indicating that the ZnO is partially reduced, resulting in the formation of Zn species at high reduction temperature. These Zn species then fuse and infiltrate with with Pt, leading to the formation of the PtZn intermetallic compound. This transformation significantly alters the geometric and electronic structure of the Pt sites on the catalyst surface [20,21]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions for the Pt/ZnO catalysts reduced at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 3. The structural properties of the catalysts are listed and compared in Table 1. The specific surface area (SBET), average pore size (Vp), and average pore volume (Dp) of the catalysts decrease gradually with increasing the reduction temperature, with the specific surface area decreasing from 45.6 to 35.9 m2 g−1, which may be the result of partial blockage of the catalyst pore channels by the Pt or PtZn intermetallic compound nanoparticles at high temperature. To further investigate the special structure of the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst, it is further characterized by TEM (as shown in Fig. 4). The PtZn intermetallic compound nanoparticles with an average particle size of 2.8±1.1 nm are highly dispersed on the ZnO (Fig. 4a). The lattice spacing in the red part in Fig. 4b is about 0.204 nm, which corresponds well with the (200) plane of PtZn intermetallic compound [22,23]. In addition, HAADF-STEM images with the corresponding EDS mapping of the Pt/ZnO-H500 sample (as shown in Figs. 4c and 4d) indicate that the Pt, Zn, and O elements are homogenously dispersed throughout the catalyst. Additionally, the absence or near-complete leaching of the Cl element derived from the Pt precursor indicates efficient removal of the impurities or precursors during the catalyst preparation process. This is important as residual impurities or precursors can negatively affect the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst. The electronic properties of Pt and Zn species in the catalysts are investigated by the XPS spectra, as shown in Fig. 5. The binding energy data for the peaks is listed in Table S2. The Pt 4 f7/2 XPS spectrum for the Pt/ZnO-H200 sample exhibits two Pt species, with the maxmia at 71.6 eV and 72.4 eV (Fig. 5a). The former can be assigned to Pt0 whereas the latter can be associated to Pt2+ species [17,24]. The PtOx species may be originated from the oxidation by exposure to ambient air. When the reduction temperatures increase from 200 °C to 400 °C or 500 °C, the binding energy due to Pt0 species shifts from approximately 71.6 eV to 71.0 eV, and the same variation trend is observed in the Pt 4 f5/2 XPS spectra. This increased reduction temperatures promote the interaction between Pt and ZnO, leading to the transfer of Pt in its reduction state from a monometallic form to an alloy compound [25,26]. As regards Zn 2p3/2 XPS spectra (Fig. 5b), there is one Zn2+ peak at nearly 1021.8 eV due to ZnO while no peak attributed to Zn0 is observed in the Pt/ZnO samples reduction at different temperatures [26]. However, there is a slight shift from 1021.8 eV to 1022.0 eV observed for the binding energy of Zn 2p3/2 when the reduction temperatures increase. It may be originated from the partial reduction of ZnO, as confirmed by the H2-TPR results. Ultimately, the XPS results indicate the transfer of electrons from the reduced Zn species to Pt, creating an electron-rich environment near the Pt sites, which further indicates the formation of the PtZn intermetallic compound phase [27,28]. The CO probe adsorption is commonly used to identify the active sites of catalysts. To further investigate the changes in the properties of Pt sites under different reduction temperature treatments, in situ CO-DRIFTS characterization is carried out on Pt/ZnO catalysts reduced at different temperatures (200, 400, and 500 °C), and the results are shown in Fig. 6. Due to the high dispersion of Pt sites in the catalysts prepared by the strong electrostatic adsorption method, only the infrared absorption peaks of linear CO adsorption are manifested in all three catalysts [29,30]. The intensity of the linearly adsorbed CO peak decreases with increasing reduction temperature of the catalysts, as well as the peak positions are red shifted. This phenomenon is similar with the previous study by Gao et al.[23]. The CO-Chem characterization (as described in Table 1) also indicates that the amount of CO adsorbed onto the catalyst and the calculated Pt dispersion gradually decreases as the reduction temperature increases. It can be attributed to the partial agglomeration of Pt or the masking of some Pt sites by reduced Zn [25]. While the red shift of the CO peak indicates a more abundant electron density of Pt on the high-temperature reduction catalyst, which can be reasonably explained by the transfer of electrons from Zn to Pt [31]. 3.2 Continuous-flow selective hydrogenation of BYD over Pt/ZnO catalyst The catalytic performance of Pt/ZnO catalysts prepared through the coupling of strong electrostatic adsorption and reactive metal-support interaction strategies is evaluated in selective hydrogenation of BYD under the conditions of 1 MPa H2, 80 °C in the continuous-flow reactor, as shown in Fig. 7. In essence, the hydrogenation of BYD engenders a cornucopia of pivotal intermediates, such as BED, butane-1,4-diol (BDO), butanol (BOL), 4-hydroxybutanal, and tetrahydrofuran-2-ol (2-OH-THF), as depicted in Fig. 7a. Clearly, the conversion of BYD increases while the selectivity for BED experiences a noteworthy decline with the progressive increase in the contact time across all Pt/ZnO catalysts (Fig. 7b). The profound interaction between Pt and ZnO, along with the formation of PtZn intermetallic compound, boosts the catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of BYD. At an identical contact time (214 gcat. h mol−1), the conversion of BYD over Pt/ZnO catalysts increases as the reduction temperature of the catalysts rises, despite the significant decrease in the dispersion of Pt or PtZn nanoparticles (refer to Table 1). The conversion of BYD is as the follow order: Pt/ZnO-H600 (92%) > Pt/ZnO-H500 (81%) > Pt/ZnO-H400 (76%) > Pt/ZnO-H200 (58%). The BED selectivity can be reached to >85% over Pt/ZnO catalysts reduced among 200 °C to 500 °C, while the Pt/ZnO-H600 catalyst presents the lowest BED selectivity (65%). The Ptδ−-Znδ+ configuration and the consequent reduction in Pt surface density induced by Zn adornment exert profound influences on the adsorption architectures and bonding potency of the reactants and intermediates, ultimately bestowing a favorable hydrogenation characteristic [10]. The limited selectivity observed for the Pt/ZnO-H600 catalyst primarily arises from the detrimental sublimation of Zn species at elevated reduction temperatures, consequently resulting in the destruction of the PtZn structure. The phenomenon bears resemblance to the TG/DTG results observed for the PdZn sample under a H2 atmosphere [2,32]. As depicted in Fig. 7c, the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst exhibits a substantially higher BED selectivity compared to other catalysts, showcasing a gradual decrease from 92% to 77% as the conversion of BYD increases from 25% to 99%. Combined with the H2-TPR and XPS results, the complete reduction of high-valent Pt species as well as the formation of PtZn intermetallic compound enhance the dispersion of Pt sites and tone its electronic properties, which promotes the BED selectivity at elevated levels of BYD conversion. The TOF values for the Pt/ZnO catalysts are calculated based on the actual Pt loadings, dispersion, and the initial conversion of substrate (as outlined in Table 1). Notably, the TOF of Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst (1421.6 h−1) surpasses that of the Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst by nearly 8 fold. The enhancement in TOF may result from its unique structure of the PtZn intermetallic compound, in which the Pt sites exist in an isolated electron-rich state, thereby augmenting the conversion of BYD at a single active site. In addition, the Pt sites within PtZn intermetallic compound exhibit a propensity for desorption rather than over-hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis of BED, underscoring their high selectivity towards BED. We further conducted a thorough comparison of the performance of Pt-based catalysts in various literature sources pertaining to the selective hydrogenation of BYD [5–10,33–35]. Table 2 shows that Pt/ZnO-H500 synthesized in this work presents a similar catalytic activity with the PtZnx/CeO2 catalyst (>80% yield to BED) [10]. It further affirms the exceptional semihydrogenation capabilities of the PtZn intermetallic compound. Evidently, when compared to monometallic Pt-based catalysts, the intermetallic PtZn catalyst shows superior selectivity hydrogenation properties, which can be as an alternative Pt-based catalyst for avoiding using the organic or amino modifications for the metallic active sites. The effect of both reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure on the performance of the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst has been thoroughly examined, and the outcomes are visually depicted in Fig. 8. As the reaction temperature escalates from 70 °C to 110 °C alongside an increase in hydrogen pressure from 0.5 MPa to 2.5 MPa, there is a notable upsurge in the conversion of BYD. However, this favorable trend is accompanied by a decline in selectivity towards BED. It can easily lead to over-hydrogenation of BED to BDO under severe reaction environments. Therefore, to ensure the optimal selective hydrogenation of BYD into BED using the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst, it is advisable to operate under mild conditions (80 °C, 1 MPa and contact time 143 gcat h mol−1). Kinetic experiments have been conducted on three Pt/ZnO catalysts, each subjected to different reduction temperatures (200 °C, 400 °C, and 500 °C), and the corresponding outcomes are shown in Fig. 9. It is observed that the rate of BYD consumption (-ln(1-X)) exhibits a linear dependence on the contact time under the reaction condition at 60 °C, thereby indicating that the BYD hydrogenation over Pt/ZnO catalysts follows a pseudo-first-order reaction kinetics, as illustrated in Fig. 9a. The calculated rate constants for the Pt/ZnO-H200, Pt/ZnO-H400, Pt/ZnO-H500 catalysts are 0.22 s−1, 0. 23 s−1, and 0.32 s−1, respectively. This further supports the notion that the formation of PtZn intermetallic compound boosts the catalytic activity by providing an abundance of isolated electron-rich Pt sites. Fig. 9b shows the Arrhenius plot for the Pt/ZnO catalysts. Despite the reduced dispersion of Pt due to the aggregation of the active metal at higher reduction temperatures, the formation of the PtZn intermetallic compound results in a lower apparent activation energy for the surface-exposed Pt sites compared to monometallic Pt catalysts. Notably, the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst exhibits the lowest activation energy for the hydrogenation of BYD (35.5 kJ mol−1), which is significantly inferior to that observed with the Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst (49.9 kJ mol−1). The Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst showcases a notable decrease in activation energy, likely originating from the robust adsorption of Ptδ- active sites onto the BYD molecule. This not only facilitates the activation of the BYD substrate but also promotes the timely desorption of hydrogenation product (BED). 3.3 The stability testing of Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst The stability of Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst for selective hydrogenation of BYD was tested under 80 °C, 1 MPa H2, and 214 gcat h mol−1 contact time. The results, shown in Fig. 10, indicate that the conversion of BYD gradually increases from 86% to 99% and then remains unchanged. This suggests that the catalyst is stable and maintains its activity throughout the testing period. The selectivity to BED is also maintained at a stable level of 85% for 75 h. The BED yield is approximately 83% and remains stable throughout the entire test process. This indicates that the catalyst is not only stable in terms of conversion but also in terms of selectivity and yield. To further investigate the electronic properties of the catalysts, XPS characterization is carried out. Fig. 11 shows that XPS results for the fresh and spent catalysts. It is found that the binding energy of the Pt 4 f does not shift after the stability testing. This suggests that the Pt atoms remain in an electron-rich state, which explains the high activity of the PtZn catalyst observed during the stability testing. Additionally, the peak of Zn 2p3/2 is shifted towards a lower binding energy in the spent catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst. This shift may be attributed to the Zn species being in a reduced state due to losses under prolonged hydrothermal conditions. The XRD patterns shown in Figure S3 confirm that the structure of the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst is relatively stable. For the spent catalyst, only the diffraction peaks of ZnO and the quartz sand used for dilution are found. The weak PtZn diffraction peak gradually disappears, which is possibly attributed to the oxidation of some Zn species in the PtZn intermetallic compound under hydrothermal reduction conditions. This finding is consistent with the XPS results. 4 Conclusions The intermetallic PtZn/ZnO catalyst, generated by the strong electrostatic adsorption of Pt on ZnO and the reactive metal-support interaction coupling strategy, has shown excellent performance in continuous flow selective hydrogenation of BYD. The reduction temperature of the catalyst greatly affects its catalytic performance, with the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst, containing PtZn intermetallic compound as active sites, exhibiting a 8 times higher TOF value compared to the Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst with monometallic Pt as active sites. The Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst also has a significantly lower activation energy (35.5 kJ mol−1) compared to the Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst (49.9 kJ mol−1). Additionally, the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst shows a much higher selectivity of BED over BYD compared to the Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst at the same conversion of BYD. During the stability testing, the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst maintains a high BED selectivity of approximately 83% at 99% BYD conversion for 75 h, which can be derived from the high dispersion PtZn anchored on the ZnO support due to the strong electrostatic effects. Combined with the XPS and in situ CO- DRIFTS results, the Pt active site in the PtZn intermetallic compound has a unique electron-rich structure. This facilitates the BYD semi-hydrogenation route by lowering the activation energy of the reactants as well as altering the adsorption strength of BED. This inhibits the over-hydrogenation route, allowing for improving the selectivity to enol in the continuous hydrogenation of alkynol. Overall, the strong electrostatic adsorption and following the reactive metal-support interaction coupling strategy employed in the PtZn/ZnO catalyst offer a promising surface engineering route for enhancing and optimizing the semi-hydrogenation of Pt-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The continuous flow selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol to 2-butene-1,4-diol places high demands on the activity and stability of the catalyst. Herein, an intermetallic PtZn/ZnO catalyst is designed by using the coupling strategy of strong electrostatic adsorption and subsequent reactive metal-support interaction. The TOF value of the Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst, including PtZn intermetallic compound with electron-rich Ptδ- active sites, reaches 1421.6 h−1, which is almost 8 times higher than that of Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst with monometallic Pt as active sites. The activation energy of Pt/ZnO-H500 catalyst (35.5 kJ mol−1) is significantly lower than that of Pt/ZnO-H200 catalyst with 49.9 kJ mol−1. In addition, the Pt/ZnO-H500 presents high stability in the continuous flow selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol to 2-butene-1,4-diol for 75 h. These results suggest the intermetallic PtZn/ZnO presents as an alternative Pt-based catalyst without modification by toxic metals or organic matter and is a promising catalyst for directional hydrogenation in fine chemical synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: PtZn/ZnO intermetallic catalyst prepared by reactive metal-support interaction for the semi-hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol
